hedline.hl1: Internet Use for Travel Plans Is Leveling Off
hedline.hl2: Internet Use for Travel Plans Is Leveling Off

abstract.p: Annual study conducted by Yesawich Pepperdine Brown & Russell and Yankelovich Inc finds that increase in number of business and leisure travelers using Internet for travel planning is leveling off; cites proliferation of pop-ups, ads and links irritating users (S)

block.p: A survey shows that the growth of travel planning on the Internet is leveling off, in part because of the proliferation of pop-ups, advertisements and links irritating users.

The 2007 National Travel Monitor -- an annual study conducted by Yesawich, Pepperdine, Brown & Russell, a travel marketing firm, and Yankelovich Inc., a marketing research company -- surveyed 2,800 business and leisure travelers. It found that in the first part of 2007, 66 percent of leisure travelers used the Internet regularly for travel planning, while in 2005, 59 percent used it, an increase of 7 percentage points. From 2002 through 2004, the percentage grew 10 points, from 53 to 63.

The 2007 National Travel Monitor -- an annual study conducted by Yesawich, Pepperdine, Brown & Russell, a travel marketing firm, and Yankelovich Inc., a marketing research company -- surveyed 2,800 business and leisure travelers. It found that in the first part of 2007, 66 percent of leisure travelers used the Internet regularly for travel planning, while in 2005, 59 percent used it, an increase of 7 percentage points. From 2002 through 2004, the percentage grew 10 points, from 53 to 63.
Use by business travelers actually dropped to 66 percent this year from 68 percent in 2005, while it rose from 55 percent in 2002 to 69 percent in 2004.

''The surge of growth we saw between 1998 and 2003 is gone,'' said Peter C. Yesawich, the chairman and chief executive of Yesawich, Pepperdine. ''To some extent, this happens with every technology as the novelty wears off.''

But he added that the ''contamination of sites,'' with links and advertisements crowding Web sites, was confirmed by the study to be an issue. ''Now consumers have to pick through all the results that get in front of their search.''
